attributes.description: Son of Daśaratha and heir of Ikshváku, currently undergoing fourteen years of banishment.
Daughter of Janak and wife of Ráma; also referred to as the Maithil dame and Videhan lady.
Son of Sumitrá and loyal brother to Ráma, serving as his protector during the exile.
A high-souled hermit residing at Prayág near the confluence of the Gangá and Yamuná.
The Goddess of the holy stream, spouse of the God o'er floods, originating from Brahmá's sphere.
Another name for the river Yamuná, personified as the Sun-born Goddess.
A holy mountain with varied peaks, located ten leagues from Prayág, chosen as Ráma's forest home.
The sacred confluence where the Yamuná and Gangá rivers meet.
The forced exile of Ráma from Ayodhyá due to Kaikeyí's wish.
The sacred Hindu texts (Vedas) prescribing religious rites and social duties.

attributes.context: Ráma is the obedient son fulfilling his father's royal will.
Sítá offers prayers and vows of sacrifice to the Goddess for Ráma's safe return.
The trio visits Prayág to seek counsel from Saint Bharadvája.
The hermit recommends the holy mount of Chitrakúma as a suitable home for the exiles.
Ráma accepts forest life to uphold duty and his father's honor.
LakshmaG is the son of Sumitrá, sent to Ayodhyá in his brother's lament.
The waves of the Gangá are said to descend from Brahmá's sphere.
